participants: cross talk - a podcast about crosswords - listen on apple podcasts or spotify

messages.message: anyone else having issues pip installing libnfs in their virtualenv because of missing <nfsc/libnfs.h>?
I already brew installed libnfs
and the header exists at `./usr/local/Cellar/libnfs/4.0.0/include/nfsc/libnfs.h` but I'm guessing pip doesn't know to look for it there?
I remember someone else ended up setting up a symlink for a missing dynlib, is this a similar issue?
oh i think i ran into that issue too… i think i was the one that set up that symlink haha
It’s true! https://instabase.slack.com/archives/C06FA6A23/p1566419840401100
:slightly_smiling_face:
hehe yep that sounds about right
what i'm puzzled by is how @cross talk - a podcast about crosswords - listen on apple podcasts or spotify didn't run into this issue

messages.sender: cross talk - a podcast about crosswords - listen on apple podcasts or spotify
messages.message: yeah i didn’t have to do any symlinking…
oh actually, mine is complaining about a missing header file. @Jonathan Shih was your error message about missing dynlib?
hmmmm
pip install requirements.txt just worked for you right colin?
it was originally complaining about the header file too
let me see if i can figure out what header files it’s referring to
can you paste the full error message? does it say where it’s looking for the header file?
posted https://instabase.slack.com/archives/C06FA6A23/p1566942175462600

can you find the nfsc folder in any other directories? i forgot which package it was for, but there was a package that failed to delete all of its folders, so it was trying to find a file in an old directory path
`find /usr/ -name nfsc -type d -ls`
can also try searching for libnfs
Is a quick way to find any lingering directories, in `/usr/` at least. Change that as needed :slightly_smiling_face:

oh actually, i found it haha. @lydia i have a symlink from /usr/local/Cellar/python/3.7.4/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.7/include/python3.7m/nfsc -> /usr/local/Cellar/libnfs/4.0.0/include/nfsc/
if you’re doing this in python2, you might need to adjust accordingly for python2
yea it seems like the issue is that brew didn't link it in /usr/local/include. i wonder why...
thank you though!!
lemme try symlinking
haha yeah.. idk which package manager is at fault
oh wait it did symlink it. i am blind. hmm even more confused
oh hmm lol

do you know if this is an osx 10.14 issue? i read something online about it moving header files from /usr/include to /Applications/Xcode.app/Contents/Developer/Platforms/MacOSX.platform/Developer/SDKs/MacOSX10.14.sdk/usr/include
maybe the issue is it's not including /usr/local/include when compiling?
lol it’s possible i guess. you can try symlinking to the xcode directory too
btw, it seems from the logs that it was looking in /usr/local/Cellar/python@2/2.7.16/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/include/python2.7. do you have nfsc symlinked into that directory too?
this worked for me `pip install --global-option='build_ext' --global-option='-I/usr/local/include' --global-option='-L/usr/local/lib' libnfs`
i don't know why i have to specify this... but brew actually correctly installed everything in /usr/local. it just seems like pip is not looking there for headers/libs
my guess is ^ will fix it for any other wheels you have to build that need headers that are installed via brew
like libxml
lol so weird. well glad you figured it out haha. wonder if there are issues with our dev setup doc now too
yea this fix seems so janky though haha
i wonder if it's an outstanding issue with mojave
Is it in a virtualenv?
though this is from 2015 https://stackoverflow.com/questions/33513522/when-installing-pyaudio-pip-cannot-find-portaudio-h-in-usr-local-include
yea in a virtualenv
